Certainly! Here are some overviews with stats on Asia-Africa travel arrivals:

1. Asia-Africa Tourism Arrivals:

In 2019, the total number of international tourist arrivals in Africa was 67 million, an increase of 4% compared to 2018. Out of these arrivals, approximately 5.5 million were from Asia, accounting for about 8.2% of the total arrivals.

According to the World Tourism Organization (UNWTO), the top source markets for African destinations in 2019 were:

* Europe (69% of all arrivals)
* America (7% of all arrivals)
* Asia and the Pacific (8.2% of all arrivals)
* Middle East (4.2% of all arrivals)
1. Chinese Tourists in Africa:

China is a significant player in the global tourism industry and has been an increasingly important source market for African destinations. In 2019, approximately 1.4 million Chinese tourists visited Africa, accounting for about 26% of all Asian arrivals in the continent.

According to the UNWTO, the top African destinations for Chinese tourists in 2019 were:

* Egypt (40% of all Chinese arrivals)
* South Africa (15% of all Chinese arrivals)
* Morocco (9% of all Chinese arrivals)
* Tunisia (6% of all Chinese arrivals)
1. African Tourists in Asia:

The number of African tourists traveling to Asia is relatively small compared to the number of Asian tourists visiting Africa. In 2019, approximately 450,000 African tourists visited Asia, accounting for about 0.7% of all international arrivals in the continent.

According to the UNWTO, the top Asian destinations for African tourists in 2019 were:

* China (20% of all African arrivals in Asia)
* India (15% of all African arrivals in Asia)
* Malaysia (13% of all African arrivals in Asia)
* Thailand (12% of all African arrivals in Asia)

In conclusion, while the number of Asian tourists visiting Africa has been increasing in recent years, it is still a relatively small portion of the total international arrivals in the continent. On the other hand, the number of African tourists traveling to Asia is still quite low. However, there is potential for increased collaboration and tourism growth between the two regions, as both have unique cultural and natural offerings that could attract visitors from around the world.
